paragraphs.name: f044
paragraphs.text: Working with the DOM API is hard. React basically gives developers the ability to work with a virtual browser that is faster and more friendly than the real browser. React’s virtual browser acts like an agent between the developer and the real browser.

paragraphs.name: cef1
paragraphs.text: This is the moment when React will potentially blow your mind. If you try to type something in the text box of the JS version, you won’t be able to. This is very much expected because we’re basically throwing away the whole DOM node on every tick and regenerating it. However, if you try to type something in the text box that’s rendered with React, you can certainly do so!

paragraphs.name: 9a7d

paragraphs.text:
open index.html # On Mac
explorer index.html # On Windows

paragraphs.name: 8df6
paragraphs.text: Instead of working with strings (as we did in the native JavaScript example above), in React, we work with objects. Any HTML string will be represented as an object using a React.createElement call (which is the core function in the React API).

paragraphs.name: 5c1f
paragraphs.text: React is a JavaScript library. It’s not a framework. It’s not a complete solution and we’ll often need to use more libraries with React to form any solution. React does not assume anything about the other parts in any full solution. It focuses on just one thing, and on doing that thing very well.

Where React really shines, is in updating the whole DOM chunks smartly, thanks to reconciliation algorithm you’ve mentioned. So, my…

paragraphs.name: 08c8
paragraphs.text: Very nice article. This is the best and easy way to understand how React is different regards to other framework. First its a library and not framework and second it doesn't not enhance HTML but rather works on JavaScript with virtual DOM which renders only the difference of state to html DOM. Great to understand this fact.
